1860 Catalogue, Page 3 - Advertisement

Artefact Types
Regions
Locations

Transcription

ADVERTISEMENT.

THE articles which compose this Museum were supplied
chiefly by the Missionaries employed by the London Mis-
sionary Society; a few others are donations from benevolent
travellers, or friendly officers of mercantile vessels. The
Missionaries rightly judged that the natural productions of
the distant countries in which they reside would be accept-
able at home, especially to their juvenile friends, and to
others who may not have opportunity of viewing larger
Collections. The efforts also of natural genius, especially
in countries rude and uncivilized, afford another class of
interesting curiosities ; whilst they prove how capable even
the most uncivilized of mankind are of receiving that in¬
struction, which it is the study of the Missionaries to com-
municate.

But the most valuable and impressive objects in this Col¬
lection, are the numerous, and (in some instances) horrible,
IDOLS, which have been imported from the South Sea
Islands, from India, China, and Africa; and among these,
those especially which were given up by their former wor
shippers, from a full conviction of the folly and sin of idolatry
—a conviction derived from the ministry of the Gospel by
the Missionaries.
A 2

Notes

  1. ↩︎
  2. ↩︎
  3. ↩︎

1860 Catalogue, Page 4 - Advertisement continued

Artefact Types
Regions
Locations

Transcription

ADVERTISEMENT.

It is hoped that a view of these “trophies of Chris-
tianity” will inspire the spectators with gratitude to God
for his great goodness to our native land, in favouring us so
abundantly with the means of grace, and the knowledge of
his salvation ; and at the same time, with thankfulness that
these blessings have, in some happy degree, been com¬
municated, and by our means, to the distant isles of the
Southern Ocean. Many of the articles in this Collection are
calculated to excite, in the pious mind, feelings of deep
commiseration for the hundreds of millions of the human
race, still the vassals of ignorance and superstition; whilst
the success with which God has already crowned our labours,
should act as a powerful stimulus to efforts, far more zealous
and extended, for the conversion of the heathen.
ud logeoD odi
8A

1860 Catalogue, Page 5

Artefact Types Idols of Heathen Nations
Regions Pacific
Locations Otaheite [Tahiti, French Polynesia]

Transcription

MISSIONARY MUSEUM.

IDOLS, AND OBJECTS OF SUPERSTITIOUS REGARD,
FROM ISLANDS IN THE PACIFIC OCEAN.

THE mission to the South Sea Islands was the earliest under-
taken by this Society. The first party of missionaries, about
thirty in number, arrived by the ship Duff at Tahiti on the 6th
of March, 1797.

On the 18th of July, 1812, Pomare, the late king of Tahiti,
who had always behaved in a friendly manner, declared to the
missionaries his full conviction of the truth of the gospel, and
his determination to worship Jehovah, as the only living and
true God.

His example was soon followed by the principal chiefs, who,
convinced of their idolatry, burnt their idols, destroyed their
maraes, abandoned human sacrifices and infant murders, forsook
their abominable impurities, and strictly observed the Lord’s day.
Pomare, in a letter to the missionaries, dated Feb. 19th, 1816,
when he sent his family or household idols to them, says, “1
wish you to send those idols to Britain, for the Missionary
Society, that they may know the likeness of the gods that Tahiti
worshipped.” The original letter, with the idols alluded to, and
numerous others from different Islands, will be found in

Case A.

1 TEMEHARO, the principal idol of Pomare’s family, one of the
chief deities of Tahiti and also the protector of Mateo.

2 TERIAPARURA, son of the great God Oro, and national pro-
tector of Tahiti, Raiatea, Huahine, Tahaa, Borabora, and
Marua.

3 Name unknown.

Notes

  2. ↩︎

  5. ↩︎
  6. ↩︎
  7. ↩︎
  8. ↩︎
  9. ↩︎

1860 Catalogue, Page 6

Artefact Types Idols of Heathen Nations
Regions Pacific
Locations Eimeo, Otaheite [Tahiti, French Polynesia],Hervey or Navigators Islands,Huahine,Rarotonga [Cook Islands],Rurutu [French Polynesia]

Transcription

SOUTH SEA MISSION. Green.

4 TIIPA, very powerful, and said to preside over the winds.

5—7 ORAMATUAs, spirits of deceased relations, to whom prayers were offered for the recovery of sick persons, &c.

8 VARUA INO, Evil Spirit. A name by which idols are now gene-
rally designated.

9—11 Idols, which, like all the preceding, are made of cinet or
braided cord, formed of fibres of the husk of the cocoa-
nut ; the first, having rude features, is TANGAROA.—Pre¬
sented by the late Mr. Bennet.

12 ORO, the god of war. A rude uncarved staff of hard casuarina
wood, said by Mr. Ellis* to have been decorated with
feathers. It was the cause of many battles ; and human
sacrifices were offered to it.—Presented by the late Mr.
Bennet.

13 A small column of basalt, worshipped by the royal family of
Tahiti, when staying at the southern part of Eimeo.—
Presented by the late Mr. Bennet.

14 Another from the same place.

15 Another stone idol, to which this silly legend was attached:
that the priest could throw it into the sea, and make it
swim back again. [see handwritten note]

16 A long carved wooden idol, beset with curved spines, and
having six small heads at top; large spider-shells are also
suspended from it. Hervey, or Navigators’ Islands.

17 Sacred ornament from a canoe; the two heads at top were
worshipped by fishermen at Huahine. (See Ellis, fig. 6.)

18—20 Three carved staff-shaped idols, like the large one
covered with cloth from Rarotonga.

21 Another, shorter, with a head at each end, and ornamented
with a few feathers, from Rarotonga.

22 TAAROA UPAO VAHO, from Rurutu, the supreme deity of Poly-
nesia. In addition to the demi-gods that stud the out-
side, designed to show the many that had proceeded from
him, a number of small idols were found in the interior
of this deity, deposited there probably to imbibe his

  • Polynesian Researches, vol. ii. p. 220.

idol is in the form of a huge stone bait of a gigantic fish-hook. It the …? were light enoguh to float the boat, the priset cerntally could have affixed a very fine line, and ran pulled the hook beach to land unseen

Artefact Types Idols of Heathen Nations

Locations Atui,Mangaia, Hervey Islands,Maute [Ma’uke, Cook Islands],Natipaki, Reiatea and Ruruti,Nukunoni, Reiatea and Ruruti,Orutanga [Arutanga, Aitutaki, Cook Islands],Otaheite [Tahiti, French Polynesia],Rarotonga [Cook Islands],Reiatea and Ruruti

Transcription

SOUTH SEA MISSION. Green.

supernatural powers, prior to their dispersion as his
representatives. (Ellis, vol. ii. page 220.)

23 Another form of TAAROA, left as his representative at the
great marae, in the district of Natipaki. (See Ellis, fig. 3.)
24 Like the last.

25 TANGAROA from Maute, with feathers and fibre cinet ap-
pended to it.

26 A carved flat club-formed idol, with an appendage of plaited
cocoa-nut fibre.

27, 28 Two, resembling the last, with feather appendages.

29 A ditto of RUATABu, with two heads and two cinet ap-
pendages. Nukunoni was the district to which it be
longed, and it was placed at the marae, to superintend their
affairs and make them victorious in war.

30, 31 Two elaborately carved club-formed idols, whose names
are now lost; they were district gods of Mangaia, one of
the Hervey Islands.

32 A larger ditto.

33 TE BuA KINA, three sons of the great RONGA, gods of the sea,
to whom prayers were offered for the safety of canoes.

34 RONGA, a rude human figure, covered with feathers, belonging
to Orutanga, a district of Aitutaki.

35 TARIGNARUE, the superior god of Atui; a very deeply carved
idol with red feathers, also, a large piece made of cinet
and feathers. These are but portions of the god; the rats,
having made a nest in him, destroyed the remainder.

36 A rope idol, with limbs covered with red feathers.

37, 38 Two narrow flat idols, covered with red feathers, and a
profusion of the tail feathers of the Tropic bird.

39 TII Vahe. A Tahitian goddess.

40 Ditto ditto. They are rudely carved human figures.

41 Another Tahitian idol, with numerous black figures painted
on it. (See Ellis, vol. i. page 24.)—Presented by the late
Rev. Rowland Hill.

42 A large well-finished figure, cut out of hard wood, with three
demi-gods attached to the breast. From Rarotonga.

Artefact Types Idols of Heathen Nations
Regions Pacific
Locations Kairua, Hawaii,Rarotonga [Cook Islands],Metiaro [Miti’aro, Cook Islands],Maute [Ma’uke, Cook Islands],Samoa,Hervey Islands,Sandwich Islands [Hawai’i, USA],Marquesan Islands

Transcription

SOUTH SEA MISSION. Green.

43 TARIA NUI, or great ears, a fishing god. (See Ellis, fig. 7.)

44 An idol made of a compact species of coral.

45 A large wooden idol, with very prominent grotesque features,
from the Sandwich Islands. Taken, with permission of
the governor, Kuakene, from the walls of an ancient marae
at Kairua, Hawaii, by the Deputation.

46 The god of thunder, of carved wood, adorned with feathers.
From Rarotonga.

47 Another resembling it.

48 A ditto, without feathers.

49 Idols from Metiaro: one resembles the last.

50 ROMATANE, from Maute, adorned with a long tail of cock’s
feathers, and tufts of human hair.

51 KAU, an idol of stone.

52 HAU, from Maute. Several clusters of feathers attached to
pieces of wood and fibre rope.

53 An idol of two figures, one on the head of the other, with
black markings and feathers.

54 TIKIHE ATUA, a rude sitting figure, with a tuft of cock’s fea-
thers on the head, taken from a canoe. Haraa

55 Two large paddle-shaped idols, with fibre rope attached.

56—60 A SAMOAN GOD, a short round’ stick; and numerous
small variously shaped idols, some decorated with fea-
thers.

61, 62 Propitiatory offerings to RoNGA and TAGNAROA, to appease
them when removed to new habitations: Hervey Islands.

63—66 Numerous bunches of feathers, probably portions of
broken idols or propitiatory offerings.

67—70 Four amulets of green Jade stone. New Zealand.

71 A tabooing rod, or else a rod carried before royalty at the
Sandwich Isles.

72 Handle of the sacred fan, TAHIVI ANUNACHAUS. (See No a,
Missionary Sketches.)

73, 74 Two sacred fans, with which the priests drove away flies
at the human sacrifices. The first is from the Marquesan
Islands.

SOUTH SEA MISSION. Green.

75 A whip, or fly-flap, made of cocoa-nut fibre. (See Ellis, vol.
ii. page 54.)

76—80 Various whips; one of the handles is of carved bone, the
others wood.

On the Floor under the north Skylight.

A GIGANTiC IDOL, twelve feet high, covered with bark cloth, orna-
mented with black zigzag lines, brought from RAROTONGA,
by the lamented Missionary, the Rev. JoH Williams.
(See his Missionary Enterprises, chap. vii.)

(For Case B, see page 46.)

Case C.

ARTICLES OF DRESS, DOMESTIC UTENSILS, IMPLE-
MENTS OF WAR, MUSIC, &c., FROM ISLANDS IN
THE PACIFIC OCEAN.

SOCIETY AND FRIeNDY ISLES.

81 Cap, or head-dress, of feathers, worn by a chief mourner.
Tahiti.—Presented by the late Rev. John Williams.

82 Ditto, worn formerly by the master of the ceremonies of the
native dances, but latterly by the chief judge of the Island
of Aitutaki.—Presented by the late Rev. John Williams
(See Missionary Enterprises, chap. xxx.)

83, 84 Two other dancer’s caps, also richly ornamented with
feathers, and rattles of pearl shells.

85 A lofty cap of red and black feathers, the back, like all the
above, covered with a profusion of human hair.

86, 87 Cloth made of bark of the paper mulberry tree, (Brous-
sonetia papyrifera.) The devices are cut out of dark cloth
and stuck on.

88—98 Various specimens of bark cloth, plain, printed, and var-
nished. For an interesting account of the whole art of
this manufacture, see Ellis, vol ii. page 173.

1860 Catalogue, Page 10

Artefact Types Manufactures, Domestic Utensils,Dresses
Regions Pacific
Locations Otaheite [Tahiti, French Polynesia],Society and Friendly Isles,Ruruta

Transcription

SOUTH SEA MISSION. Green.

99, 100 Mallets or cloth-beaters, being grooved instruments of
casuarina wood. Tahiti.

101 Engraved narrow slips of bamboo, used for printing on the
cloth.

102 Combs made of the stalks of cocoa-nut leaflets, neatly tied,
side by side.

103 A spoon, with two bowls.

104—106 PENU, or bread-fruit pounders, made of basalt. Tahiti.

107 Ditto, made of coral, of the genus Astrea. Ruruta.—Pre¬
sented by Mr. Ellis.

108—110 Adzes, for breaking the bread-fruit; of three sorts of
wood. (Ellis, vol. ii. p. 54.)

111—113 Instruments for the same purpose, made of the
casuarina and cocoa-nut wood.

114, 115 Files make of shark’s skin.

116—120 Various sized adzes, the blades made of basalt.

121 A ditto, with a handle elaborately carved, and neatly tied.
Mangaia. (See Williams’s Missionary Enterprises, page 264.)

122 A small ditto, of brown jasper, from Sir Charles Sander’s
Island.

123, 124 Loose basaltic adze heads.

125, 126 Three flutes, made of bamboo. Tahiti.

127—132 Five fish-hooks, made of wood, and the haft of one of
mother of pearl.

133, 134 Decoys for catching cuttle-fish, made of portions of
various species of Cypræae.

135—138 Various specimens of cordage made of cocoa-nut fibre.

139, 140 Two baskets made of ditto, ornamented with shell-
beads.

141 An ornament for the head, made of the same.

142 Two warrior’s belts, composed of rows of bone beads rudely
carved.

143 > A ditto, of tufts of hair.

144, 145 Two of cordage, with carved bone ornaments.

Green.)
New ZEALAND.
146 Jadé-stone ear-drops.

mented. The notes resemble the yells of savages.

five species of land-shells.—Presented by Mr. Ellis.

1860 Catalogue, Page 12

SAMOAN GROUP AND SUNDRIES.
202* O LE PULoro, or OLE Faa Ale, a musical instrument, used
when a chief is taken ill.
203 Various mats, made of the pandanus leaf by natives, and
worn as dresses.

books to school.
205 Two very beautiful rugs, received in 1840, from one of the

New Holland.

225 Basket for partition.
226 Basket for catching a small kind of worm, of greenish colour,
called by the Samoans “ Palolo.” The natives are ex¬
tremely fond of it as an article of food.

CHINESE MISSION.
Yellow.
4 QUANTECONG, supposed by the Chinese to have been their first
emperor. This and the two preceding are of carved
wood, richly gilt and coloured.
5 Ditto of coarse pottery, also coloured.
6 A figure of KvLIN, a fabulous beast, supposed to have appeared
at the birth of Confucius, and thought to be ominous of
good fortunes to the young.
S
7, 8 Two of WAN CHaNG, the god of letters, made of white metal,
rather softer than pewter.
9 KwAN YIN, of gilt marble. (See No. 38 of Missionary
Sketches.)—Presented by Mr. Medhurst.
10—13 Four ditto, of white porcelain.
l labe
14, 15 Two ditto, of coloured ditto.
16 A standing figure of ditto, also of white porcelain.
17, 18 Two of the Laughing BUDDHA, made of the same material.
19—21 Three small gilt figures, two of them bearded, supposed
to be idols.
22—42 Twenty various small, painted, and gilt IDOLS, wor-
shipped by the boat families.
43 LooI KoNG, the thunderer, a chief god of the Chinese.
44 A well executed historical figure in terra cotta, representing
a warrior.
45 Wax candles, used on the altars in idol-worship.
46 INCENSE STICKS, usually called Jos sticks. They are held in
the hand by worshippers, and burn like a slow match
about half-an-hour; they are also used for the measure¬
ment of time.
47 A pair of mock candles, sometimes placed before the idol.
48—55 Various candlesticks of white metal, used on the altars.
56—60 Incense vessels, made of bronze metal.
61, 62 Two large BELxs, with frames to suspend them.
63, 64 Two maces of office, made of soft metal, like pewter.
65—83 A variety of pewter vessels, as teapots, lamps, incense
pots, &c.
84, 85 A pair of carved cocoa-nut cups.—Presented by Poon a
Sam, Dr. Morrison’s servant.

228 A wAR DRess worn by the Dayaks of Borneo : it formerly

229 A cutlass used by the Dayaks of Borneo. A label attached
states that, “ Every yellow spot on the blade of this weapon
denotes a head cut off by it."—This is doubtful. The spots
appear as if inserted when the weapon was made ; possibly
the shells on one side of the hilt may have been added
for the purpose alleged.
e Aote, oweer Settir Bears dhis ond.
In Case M, against the opposite wall,
230—242 Are thirteen frames, containing eighteen model pic-
tures of Japanese costumes, which must have been
obtained at great risk, as it is punishable with death to
export from Japan anything of this kind.
243—249 Five large and two small japanned boxes.
250 A Japanese musical instrument. (On the case.)
In the case are pictures of the following Chinese Deities, &c., named
on the back by the late Dr. Morrison.
1 Name effaced.
2 TSUU TI. The Mars, or god of war.
3 POoN KAo WOANG. The first man : he is covered with leaves.
4 SAI YUN SEE TSUE Fo. The progenitor of those who tsue fo,
produce fire by the instrument soi, yet used in their
temples.
5 No label.
6 TAO TEEN teheeoo. The god of gain: it is placed in almost
every shop in Canton.

CHINESE MISSION.
Yellow.]

Over Case M are.
Twelve paintings by Fat Qua, sent from Canton, 1809, by Dr
Morrison, then resident missionary there.
No. 13 represents persons plucking leaves off the tea plant.
14 Another mode.
15 Females rolling tea, &c.
16 Placing it in the sun.
17 Sifting it.
18 Making chests for it, showing the manner in which the car-
penters work.
19 Drying the tea, &c.
20 Packing the tea.
21 The mode of packing it in chests by treading upon it.
22 A priest showing samples.
23 Putting it into boats.
24 Bringing it down the river.
To the Left are
25—34 Ten well-executed paintings of Chinese domestic scenes.
Hung against Case I.
35—39 Five paintings of Chinese at their devotions to different
idols.
40 Six coloured etchings by a Chinese artist, named Sunqua, ex¬
hibiting the PROGReSs or THe OPIU SeR from health
and prosperity, to misery and degradation, and forming
together a counterpart to Hogarth’s famous set of the
“ Rake’s Progress. —Presented by Rev. Micaiah Hill, of
Berhampore.
MONGOLIAN DEITIES.
ERLIK CHAN, the god of hell.
AMIDABA, a merciful deity.

IDOLS,AND OBJECTS OF SUPERSTITION FROMINDIA,
INCLUDING THE THREE PRESIDENCIES.
In the centre of the room.
GUADAMA, an incarnation of BUDDHA, a large Burmese idol of
marble, partly gilded.—Presented by Rev. Micaiah Hill.
In Cases F, I, and K.
1—4 Four others of Guadama, of marble, partly gilded, from
Rangoon.
5—10 Six more of gilt wood, of different sizes, and variously
supported : one rests on a three-headed elephant.
11—13 Three ditto of bronze or brass.
13* Two ditto, from Calcutta.—Presented by Rev. W. Morton.
14, 15 Two small ditto, of silver, from Rangoon.—Presented by
Miss Cheap.
15* Ditto from Calcutta.—Presented by Rev. W. Morton.
16, 17 Two silver figures of Burmese at their devotions.—Pre-
sented by Rev. M. Hill.
17* A painted wooden figure of a worshipper of Buddha, from
Calcutta.—Presented by Rev. W. Morton.
17** An altar of Buddha, of gilt bronze. Calcutta.—Presented
by Rev. W. Morton.
17*xx A shrine or temple of ditto.—Presented by Rev. W. Morton.
18 KALEE, the black goddess of cruelty, standing on the body of
her husband, SHIVU. (See No. 10 of Missionary Sketches.)
19 BALA KRISHNA, an avatara of Vishnu, at play on his knees.
20 Ditto, as MURLIDER the tuneful, playing on a pipe.
21—29 A case of rejected idols, consisting of three small bronze
figures of the BALA KRISHNA dancing; ditto on his
knees; RAMA; GANESA, and three others, from Cuddapah,
East Indies.

Vishnu.

39 LINGA, the symbol of Seeb, or Shiva.
40 NAGA LINGA NAUDI. The head of Vishnu surmounting the
four heads of Brahma, and the bull, or Naudi, in front.—
Presented by Rev. M. Hill.

43 SEEB, or SHIVA, a small bronze figure with four hands.

hands clasped.

brass.

1860 Catalogue, Page 26

Artefact Types Idols of Heathen Nations
Regions India
Locations

Transcription

[Blue.
INDIAN MISSION.
26
66 Brahminical cord, worn as a distinction of caste, thrown aside
by a Brahmin, on being baptized.
67 Fakirs mala, or necklace worn by Hindoo religious men-
dicants.
From 68—86 are painted wooden figures of the following deities,
whose histories are detailed in “ Ward’s Hindoo Mythology."”
68 CHoIror the Wise, a form of Krishnu, the god of a set of
Voiragees, or Mendicants.
69 UBHUYA.
70 LU RUHMUNU.
71 NUNDEE, one of the Bhootus.
72 KARrie, commander of the celestial armies, who rides on
a peacock.
73 JUGUDDHarree, Mother of the World; a yellow goddess dressed
in red, sitting on a lion.
74 SHIVU, the Destroyer, with his wife on his knee, riding on a
bull. His history is lasciviousness detailed, and himself
a personification of lust. It is at the annual festival of
this deity, that certain devôtees pierce their tongues, bore
their sides, swing by hooks inserted under the muscles
of the shoulder-blades, and perform other ceremonies of
self-torture.
75 RADHA, wife of Krishnu.
76 VISHNU, the Reserver. The Hindoo sacred books give ac-
counts of ten incarnations ; nine are past : in one he
assumed the shape of a tortoise, and took the new-formed
earth on his back.
77 VISwAKARMa, the Hindoo Vulcan, a monkey god, who assisted
Hunoomanu in building a bridge.
78 GUNESHu, or GANEsA, the god of prudence and policy, repre-
sented as a short man with an elephant’s head.
79 SEErA, a terrestrial goddess; was the daughter of King Januka,
and wife of Ramu: she was carried off by Ravunu by way
of reprisal.
80 JUGUNNATHU, Lord of the World. He has many temples; the
most famous is at Orissa. It is at the annual Car festival

Notes

  1. ↩︎
  2. ↩︎
  3. ↩︎
  4. ↩︎
  5. ↩︎
  6. ↩︎
  7. ↩︎

1860 Catalogue, Page 27

Artefact Types Idols of Heathen Nations
Regions India
Locations

Transcription

27
INDIAN MISSION.
Blue.
of this idol, that unnumbered multitudes of pilgrims
attend, and hundreds, perhaps thousands of diseased or
distressed persons, cast themselves under the wheels of
the ponderous car, and are crushed to death.
81 HuNooMaNU, a monkey god, who is represented as having
done wonders in the battles of Rama, and of having built
a bridge across the sea by throwing mountains into it.
82 RAMU, a deified monarch and hero of the Hindoo poem called
Ramayunu, (translated into English by the Serampore
missionaries). Many Hindoos write his name on the
breast and forehead of a dying person, who, in conse-
quence, is supposed to ascend immediately to heaven,
instead of being dragged to judgment.
83 BULURAMU, brother of Juggernaut, contemporary with Krishnu;
his image always accompanies Juggernaut.
84 SHIVU, the Destroyer. He is chiefly worshipped under the
form of Linga, and has more worshippers than all the
other gods put together. (See also No. 74.)
85 KRISHNU, a terrestrial god, and an incarnation of Vishnu.
Several festivals are held in his honour, some in the
night, accompanied by the most abominable practices.
Krishnu’s thefts, wars, and adulteries are so numerous,
that his whole history seems to be one uninterrupted
series of crimes.
86 BRUMHA, a red man with four faces. The vedas, or holy books,
are said to proceed from his four mouths.
87 GUNGA, or the River Ganges. The Hindoos not only reverence
their rivers, but actually worship them. Crowds perform
their devotions on the banks of the Ganges, and the sick
are laid there, expecting recovery from the sight of the
goddess.
88 LUKSHMEE, goddess of wealth, one of the wives of Vishnu.
89 A series of figures of baked clay, representing the ten incar-
nations or avatars of Vishnu, and named as follows:—a.
Mutsya. b. Koorma. c. Varaha. d. Narashimva. e.
Vamana. f. Paroosalama. g. Sru Rama. h. Buth Rama.
i. Boudha. j. is also called Boudha, but a different figure,
and k. Kulleka.

1860 Catalogue, Page 28

Artefact Types Dresses,Idols of Heathen Nations,Instruments of War,Manufactures, Domestic Utensils
Regions India
Locations Bengal [India],Dummul,Malabar,Mysore [Mysuru, India]

Transcription

Blue.
INDIAN MISSION.
28
These, Christian reader, are specimens of the gods of India,
worshipped by more than a hundred millions of people.
They are the creatures of a corrupt imagination, and the
work of men’s hands; “they have mouths, but they speak
not; eyes have they, but they see not; they have ears,
but they hear not ; noses have they, but they smell not;
they have hands, but they handle not ; feet have they, but
they walk not, neither speak they through their throat.
They that make them are like unto them, so is every one
that trusteth to them. O Israel, trust thou in the Lord."
—Psalm cXv. 5—9.
The ViRGi an h, from MYSORe, a well-executed carving in
wood, gilt, probably of Italian workmanship, that belonged
to native Roman Catholics, who sent it to the Missionary
Society. For an account of the high value set upon this
image, and the consternation of the people on its removal,
see the “ Missionary Chronicle for January, 1826.
90 An iron WAR CLUB of the Gosains, a sect of Hindoos who
never marry, their numbers being kept up by adopting the
children of other sects.—Presented by Rev. Micaiah Hill.
91 A large ornamental PUNKA, or fan, with long handle, made of
a talipot leaf. Bengal.
92, 93 Bangles or bracelets, worn by the lowest class of Hindoos.
—Presented by Rev. W. Crow.
94 Ditto, of brass.
95, 96 Two brass rings, and a pair of gold earrings.
97 Fragment of mosaic work, from the ceiling of an ancient
palace at Dummul.—Presented by Rev. J. Hands.
98—100 Necklaces, one of red glass beads, intersected by long
bone beads.
101 ArUrany, a richly wrought iron STYLE, with an eraser, in a
case, from Malabar. It is used for writing on slips of the
talipot leaf.
102 A manuscript in the Telugu language, on slips of the talipot
leaf.
103 Another, containing Dr. Watts’s first Catechism.
104 Another, in the Sanscrit character, with covers of wood.

tam Female Orphan School. 1838.

123 Ditto gentleman’s.

125 Another pair. Persian.

127, 128 Two of the cuddatum, a substitute for slates, with
pencils, used by merchants in keeping their accounts.
129, 130 Two bags or cases, in which letters are sent from the
Emperor of Persia to persons of distinction, one having
the imperial seal attached.
FROM CEYLON.
131—133 Cap, jacket, and trowsers, worn by persons called
YAKKA DURA, or devil dancers, who profess necromancy,
and provide people with charms, consisting of incanta-
tions, written on a piece of ola, or palm leaf, which is
rolled up and fastened to the arm, and worn openly by all
classes. Devil worship is not sanctioned by Buddhist
books, but it is now so generally associated with Buddh-
ism, as almost to threaten its extinction. Several other
jackets, all ornamented with the figure of an idol, at-
tended by Hanuman.
134 A large shawl, covered with strange devices and grotesque

1860 Catalogue, Page 31

Artefact Types Idols of Heathen Nations
Regions India
Locations Bellary [India],Burma,Travancore [Trivandrum, India]

Transcription

INDIAN MISSION.
Blue.
Case J.
1 PARAMASATTEE, a wooden idol with iron spoons attached, (see
“Missionary Magazine,” October, 1837.) The name lite-
rally signifies “heavenly virtue or strength;” this demon
being accounted the wife of the heavenly Scevan. Their
ceremonies are performed in the night ; the spoons hold
oil and wicks, and when lighted under the shade of a
banyan tree have an imposing effect. There are several
Tamil letters on the idol, five of which are considered
sacred, and the Pandarams, who teach their meaning, are
called the “ Gooroos of the five letters.
At the sides of the entrance.
2 NAGUR SWAMEE, the serpent god, formed of a dark compact
granite, from Travancore. (See “ Missionary Sketches,’
No. 61.)
3 Another, from the same place.
4 Another, with an image of VISHNU, seated within the hood of
the serpent (the Cobra de capello), from Bellary.—Pre-
sented by Rev. J. Hands.
5 SATTAN, a well cut figure of granite.
6 A pagoda and belfry of a Burmese temple. A model of a lofty
conical building, having three rows of the idol Guadama.
7 A large LINGA, the symbol of Shiva, or Seeb, made of black
marble.
On the wall.
8 A large painting of VEesaoo, or PalPA SWaMee, tutelary
deity of Travancore.
9 A pen and ink drawing of the Hindoo idol Kisnooh Abotaah,
formed by the name being repeated in every line.
10 A ditto, of Neresing Abotaah, formed in like manner. Moore,
in his “ Hindoo Mythology,” describes this as the fourth
avatara of Vishnu, Narsinha with Hivanyacasipa on his
lap.

ARTICLES OF DRESS, DOMESTIC UTENSILS, ARMS,
&c., FROMPAFRICA AND MADAGASCAR.

on public festivals.
3 Head-dresses of Hottentots, adorned with Cowry shells.
Cyprœa moneta.
4—8 Various conical hats of basket work, from the interior of
Africa.
9 Another of European fashion.
10 LITLAKA, or sandals made of hide, four pairs, worn by the
Bechuana tribe.
11, 12 Two female garments, worn behind, of skin, ornamented
with beads.
13, 14 Two Coranna, or Hottentot head-dresses.
X15, 16 Two aprons of the same material, cut into long and
slender strips. Bechuana.
17 MAKANTSA, a Bechuana sash, suspended on the hip, in their
dances.
18 A DoLL, kept by the married Bechuana women, who are
childless, as a memento until they have a child, when
it is discarded.
19 String of prognosticating dice of a Basuto, composed of
small hoofs and astragali.—Presented by the Rev. R. Moffat.
20 Two dice, of small hoofs. Lattakoo.
21 Medicinal stick, given by the Queen of Lattakoo to Mr.
Campbell.
X 22 MANYENA. Ear-drops, of brass wire. Bechuana.

Queen of Lattakoo, and presented to Mr. Campbell.
x 28 Another, of brass beads, worn by the young King of Kurree-
chane.—Presented by Mr. Campbell.

Regions Africa

[Red.
AFRICAN MISSION.
34
29—38 Various arm and leg ornaments, of brass wire, beads,
leather, &c.—Presented by the Rev. R. Moffat.
39—41 Neck, arm, and leg rings, used by wives and daughters
of the Mantatees. This is a nation in the interior of
South Africa, about 40,000 of whom left their country on
a plundering expedition, and were repulsed near Lattakoo;
these, with various other articles, were then taken. The
four rings fastened together were worn by one female.-
Presented by the. Rev. R. Moffat.
42, 43 Buttons of stone (serpentine) and glass beads.
44, 45 Two aprons, composed of long strings of reeds and peas,
worn by the female Bechuanas, in one of their ceremonies.
46 Hottentot female apron, of skin, adorned with beads.
47, 48 Two others, of glass beads.
49 A Mantatee female apron, of iron beads.—Presented by the
Rev. R. Moffat.
50 A waist lace of ditto.—Presented by the Rev. R. Moffat.
51 Another, of beads, cut out of ostrich egg-shells.
52—55 An infant’s attire of ditto, fastened round the neck and
loins to support the back; also long strings of beads, of
the same material, worn round the waist by Bechuana
females.
56 Two broad belts of the same, wornround the head by Bushmen.
57 Two other belts, probably for the head, composed of thin
slips of reed.
58 A band of Cowry shells.
59, 60 Rows of iron and brass beads. From Kurreechane.
61 A very long string of small glass beads. /7’2"
62—66 Numerous rows of dried peas, &c., &c.
67 Head-dress of skin, embellished in front with perpendicular
rows of beads, worn by an Amakosa woman.
68 Crown, or cap, worn by King Thom, at the River Congo.—
Presented by Mr. Redhead,

Red.
AFRICAN MISSION.
108 Another knife, which has the haft and sheath covered with
brass wire.—Presented by Rev. R. Moffat.
109 Coranna shaving brush, made of wood, by beating it when
green.
110 Two small iron adzes.
111 A smith’s hammer, with a handle of the rhinoceros’ horn.
112 Specimens of Bechuana copper, in the process of wire-draw-
ing, as performed in the presence of the Rev. Mr. Moffat.
113 A woman’s pick, for working the ground.
114 Iron spoon. From Bonnys.
115 A large wooden ladle for distributing boiled corn, used by
the Bechuana and Amazoola tribes.—Presented by Rev, R.
Moffat.
116 A spoon with grooved handle.—Presented by Rev. R. Moffat.
117—121 Seven wooden spoons, the handles ornamented with
carvings of the giraffe, elephant, buffalo, bird, human
head, &c.—Presented by Rev. R. Moffat.
122, 123 Ten others, of the Bechuana tribe.
124—126 Three Hottentot violins and bows; the first is a por-
tion of a gourd, the last resembles the European; they
are all covered with skin.
127 Pieces of matting used as money at the River Congo ; one
piece was considered equal to a pound of salt.
128 Plaited hair from the tail of a giraffe.
129 Hat in the European shape, made of the same ; it is of
great rarity, and highly valued at the Cape.—Presented by
Rev. R. Moffat. n ay eler.
130 Shamboc, a whip made of the skin of the rhinoceros.
131—134 Ten various Kaffir baskets, some with lids, for carrying
corn, made by the Hottentots at Bethelsdorp.
135 LEKUKA, a vessel of ox-hide for preparing milk. Bechuana.
136 Another larger vessel, being the skin of the hind portion of
an animal, with the feet on.
137—139 Two milk pails, cut out of solid wood, one from the
Coranna country.

1860 Catalogue, Page 41

Artefact Types Dresses,Idols of Heathen Nations,Instruments of War,Manufactures, Domestic Utensils
Regions Americas
Locations Arrow tribe, Guiana,Berbice [Guyana],Caribee tribe,Demerara [Guyana],Guiana

Transcription

In Case O.
AMERICA, AND THE WEST INDIES.
1 PEHI, an instrument of Obiah, or incantations, used by the
Pehemen, either to drive away sickness, or to inflict it.
The natives would not dare to shake it, except on special
occasions. They would rattle it all night over a person
who was ill, and at the same time sing their wild song.
Presented by the Rev. John Wray, Missionary, Berbice, 1818.
2 Model of an Indian hut, or Bucks’ Logie, with miniature fur-
niture and utensils, consisting of hammocks, stools, cook-
ing utensils of earthenware, baskets, clubs, and canoes.
Demerara.
3 Head ornament of red feathers.
4 Ditto, of basket-work and feathers.
5 Necklace of scarlet moboys. Adenanthera pavonina.
6, 7 Two bead aprons, worn by the female Indians of Guiana.
8 Leg-rattle, made of the woody nuts of the Cerbera thevetia,
worn by the Warrow tribe, Guiana.
9—16 Eight various ornamental baskets. Guiana.
17 A fire fan, of basket work, made of the young leaves of a
palm. From Guiana.—Presented by H. Stutchbury.
18—20 Three calabashes, neatly engraved.—Berbice.—Presented
by Rev Mr. Wray.
21—24 Four earthenware cooking vessels. Guiana.
25 QUANIA, or flute, made of bamboo, used by the Caribbee tribe.
26, 27 A quiver of poisoned darts. They are used with the
blow-pipe, No. 10, now in the lobby. From Guiana.—
Presented by H. Stutchbury.
28 Quadrangular club of hard wood, used by the Macusi and
Caribbee Indians of Guiana.—Presented by Rev. Mr. Wray.
29 Ditto, ditto, armed with a piece of wood, inserted into the
side.—Presented by Rev. Mr. Wray.

AMERICAN MISSION.
Pink.
13 A bow presumed to be used with them.

Over the Lobby Fire-place are
Twenty various bows from Tahiti, and other South Sea Islands;
the one with a groove along the front is from Tongataboo.
The two made of letter-wood, from Guiana. Another
from Peru; and three from places unknown.
Case L
Contains a very interesting collection of miscellaneous articles,
principally obtained at the different Missionary stations
during the visits of the deputation ; including the Idol
Oro’s sacred Trumpet-shell, and mother of pearl rattle ;
obtained from Pahi, the High Priest.—Breast-plate of Ta¬
matoa, King of Raiatea.—A pihi or carved chest, that held
the war ornaments of the Regent of Huahine.—Chinese
mandarin’s cap.—An ancient bronze cup, with Javanese
zodiac, from Solo.—Malay Tambourine.—Two carved
groups of Vishnu and Krishnu, with other figures from
Travancore.—Punqua from Benares.—A splendid copy
of the Burmese Sacred volume, painted on large slabs of
ivory, from Rangoon.—The four Gospels, and other
Missionary tracts, printed in several of the Oriental and
South Sea languages, &c. &c.—Presented by George
Bennet, Esq.

In the horizontal Case U.
MISCELLANEOUS ARTICLES, UNCONNECTED WITH

1 Cast of a medallion of Pope Gregory XVI.

graved on mother of pearl, at Bethlehem.—Presented by
Rev. Mr. Lowndes.
5—7 Three large mother of pearl shells, well engraved, brought
from Alexandria.—Presented by Rev. William Thompson.
8, 9 Two circular plates of wood, with inscriptions painted on
them in very old orthography.
10, 11 Two rosaries with crucifixes.
12 Feather flowers, made by the nuns at Malta.
13 A miniature copy of the Koran, written in Arabic.—Presented
by the late D. Dale, Esq., Judge of Moorshedabad; sent
by Rev. M. Hill.
14 Another, on small round pieces of paper, attached side by
side, sometimes worn by Mussulmans in a kind of locket
suspended from the neck ; this was also presented by Mr.
Dale.
15 Chinese coins attached to a small tortoise shell, and a piece
of silk.
Other coins of the following emperors:—
16 KANG-HI, who ruled from 1661 to 1722.
17 YANGSHIN, 1722 to 1735. KIEN-LUNG, 1735 to 1795.
18 KEA KING, 1795 to 1826, and one probably of the
19 MIng dynasty, which lasted from 1368 to 1649.
20 A coin of Schah ALEM II., 1758, sovereign of Delhi.

1860 Catalogue, Page 46

Artefact Types Specimens in Natural History
Regions Americas,Pacific,South East Asia,Unknown
Locations Guiana,Java [Indonesia],South Seas,West Indies

Transcription

White.
NATURAL HISTORY.
Case B.
NATURAL HISTORY.
POLYPARIA.
1 The sea fan, Gorgonia flabellum. West Indies.
2 The sea feather, Gorgonia setosa.
3 Gorgonia umbraculum. Java.
4 Gorgonia pectinata. Ditto.
5 The red-jointed coral, Mellitea ochracea. Ditto.
6 Two fine examples of the large cup-shaped pin sponge, called
NEPrUNE’s GoBLEr, Spongia patera of Hardwick. From
Java.
7 The stag’s-horn coral, Madrepora cervicornis. South Seas.
8 Madrepora abratenoides. Ditto.
9—11 Two other species of Madrepora, and one attached to a
valve of Meleagrina margaritifera. Ditto.
12 Pocillopora damicornis. Ditto.
These are the skeletons and habitations of myriads of minute
animals, that live together in societies, build in concert,
and form reefs of immense extent, or entire islands.
INSECTA.
13 Three examples of the nest of a wild bee, called by the
natives of Guiana “ Marybunters,” Epiphone nidulans;
one has been opened to show the structure of the interior.
14 The tubular case of Myale nidulans, a species of spider, that
forms a door, which closes when the creature is within.
—Presented by Dr. Hodgkin.
15 A fine example of the black Scorpion, in spirit.
16 Another species.
17—20 Bottles containing Centipedes, Myriopodæ.

1860 Catalogue, Page 47

Artefact Types Specimens in Natural History
Regions Americas,India,Pacific,Unknown
Locations Kristnapore, near Calcutta [India],South America,Sunderbunds, near Calcutta [India],Travancore [Trivandrum, India]

Transcription

47
NATURAL HISTORY.
White.1
MOLLUSCA.
21 The shells of Pinna nigrina, and various large univalves, as,
22 Triton variegatus, or trumpet-shells.
23, 24 Cassis cornutus, and Cypræacassis rufa, both used for
cutting the imitation cameos.
25 Fusus colosseus.
26 Turbo marmoratus.
27 Trochus Niloticus.
28, 29 Murex inflatus, and Pteroceras truncata.—Presented by
the late Rev. J. Williams.
REPTILIA.
30 Skull of a large CROCODILE, taken in the Sunderbunds, near
Calcutta.
31 Ditto of the GAVIAL, from the same place.—Both presented by
Rev. James Hill.
32 The stuffed skin of a MONITor, from Travancore. These
animals are venerated by natives of the warmer parts of
the old world, who assert that they give notice upon the
approach of the crocodile.
33 In spirits are two of the Gecko, a lizard whose feet are so
constructed as to enable it to walk against a smooth
ceiling, like a fly. There is also a whip snake in the same
bottle.
34 Another whip snake.
35 A fine specimen of the true BoA, also in spirit, from South
America ; it is more rare than the following.
36 The PYTHo, one of the snakes popularly called BoA CoN-
STRICTOR, killed by the Revs. Messrs. Gogerly and Croix,
at the Missionary station of Kristnapore, near Calcutta.
The capture of this animal is related in the “ Missionary
Magazine and Chronicle for July, 1836.
37—40 Four other stuffed snakes, all venomous.

[White.
NATURAL HISTORY.
41 Carapace, or back shell of a large edible Turtle, Chelonia
Midas. From the West Indies.

PISCES.
48 A stuffed specimen of the flying gurnard, Trigla volitans.

52 The sea-horse, Sygnathus hippocampus.

59, 60 Several of a very small species. From Calcutta.

Trygon.
Cases I, J, and K.
AVEs.
63 The CASSOWARY, Casuarius. From India. Like the ostrich, it
is unable to fly, but runs with great swiftness, being aided
by its short wings.
64 Eggs of the same.
65 Ostrich eggs, one rudely engraved by a Hottentot. obj-1
66 Two eggs.

69 Auk.

Lowndes, Corfu.
69** A male Vulture.—Presented by Rev. I. Loundes, Corfu.

1860 Catalogue, Page 49

Artefact Types Specimens in Natural History
Regions Africa,India,Unknown
Locations Banks of Malareen River in Bechuana Country,Bechuana country,Benares [India],India

Transcription

White.
NATURAL HISTORY.
49
70 Head of the rhinoceros Hornbill.
71 Hanging birds’-nests.
72 Skull of the shag Crane. From the Griqua country.
73 Various pheasants, partridges, &c. From India.—Presented
by Rev. R. C. Mather.
74 Two cases of insects.—Ditto.
75 A group of birds. From India.—Presented by Rev. Dr. Boaz.
MAMMALIA.
RUMINANTIA.
73 Pair of polished horns of a species of Bos.
74 The KoKoon, Catoblepas taurina of Hamilton Smith, in
Griffith’s translation of Cuvier. Shot on the banks of
the Malalareen river, in the Bechuana country, South
Africa, by Mr. Campbell’s party, July, 1823.
75 The BRiNoLep Groo, Catoblepas gorgon, Ham. Smith, but A.
taurina of Dr. A. Smith, also shot in the Bechuana country
by Mr. Campbell’s party, 1823.
76 The CAAMA, or hartebeest, Antelope bubulus, Linnæus. Mr.
Swainson has confounded this animal with the Acronotus
canna.
77 Head and horns of the Antelope bubulus.
78, 79 Head, horns, feet, and tail, of the WHITe-rA ANTeLoPe,
Antelope melampus.—Presented by Dr. Thom. These
animals are gregarious and migratory, making desolate
the tract over which they pass.
80, 81 The same parts of the GEMs-BOK, Antelope oryx.
82 Skull and horns of a small antelope.
83—86.A pair, and three odd horns of small antelopes, one of
them a gazelle’s.
87 Two skulls of the HoG DEER, from Benares.—Presented by
Rev. W. P. Lyon.
PACHYDERMATA.
88 The ZEeBRA, or wild ass, Equus zebra. These elegant quadru-
peds inhabit the plains of Africa, are gregarious, and very
swift, but being vicious, are, as yet, of little use to man.

1860 Catalogue, Page 50

Artefact Types Specimens in Natural History
Regions Africa,India
Locations Benares [India],Cape Colony [Western Cape, South Africa]

Transcription

[White.
NATURAL HISTORY.
50
RODENTIA.
88* Tsipho, or Jerboa of Scripture, which destroyed the corn of
the Philistines when the ark was taken.—Presented by Rev.
R. Moffat.
89 Skull of Hippopotamus capensis, or SEA Cow of the Cape
colonists ; formerly found in most of the large rivers of
South Africa, but is now almost extinct within the colony.
They feed on grass, chiefly during the night, and are so
timid that they retreat to the water on the approach of
man; but, if attacked in the water, often swim to the
hunter’s boat, rise suddenly beneath, and seriously injure,
if not destroy it; their flesh used to be in much request
as food, both among the natives and the colonists.—Pre-
sented by Rev. Dr. Philip.
90, 91 The lower jaw and a large tusk of hippopotami ; the
latter are very white, and much harder than ivory.
92, 93 Skin of the head of RHIoeros Africanus, with portions
of skin from other parts of the body.
94 Five Rhinoceros’ hoofs.
95 Molar tooth of the African elephant, Elephas Africanus.
96 Two ditto of the Asiatic species, E. Indicus.
97 Tails of two elephants.
98 Skull of a wild boar, Sus scrofa, of large size. From Benares.
-Presented by Rev. W. P. Lyon.
Tusks of ditto.
99 ErhoI Boar, Phascochœrus Africanus, distinct from the
boars, properly so called, having but two incisors in the
upper jaw, and six in the lower; the latter animal having
six in each.
100 Tusk of ditto.
EDENTATA.
101 CAPE ANT-EAreR, Orycteropus capensis, from the Cape of
Good Hope. It burrows in the ground, sleeps by day
and prowls by night, and is of great muscular strength.
On arriving at an ant-hill, it scratches it up with its
claws, and then protrudes the tongue, covered with a

1860 Catalogue, Page 51

Artefact Types Specimens in Natural History
Regions Africa,India,Madagascar,Unknown
Locations Benares [India],Griqua Country [Northern Cape, South Africa],Lattakoo [Dithakong or Maruping, Northern Cape, South Africa],Madagascar,Travancore [Trivandrum, India]

Transcription

White.)
NATURAL HISTORY.
51
clammy saliva, in which the ants become entangled; the
tongue is then drawn into the mouth, and thousands are
destroyed. The teeth differ from those of all other
quadrupeds, being cylinders traversed longitudinally by
small canals.
102 Skin of the SHORr-rteD MANIS, M. pentadactylus. This
also feeds on insects, and has the power of rolling itself
up as a defence from danger, presenting a formidable row
of erect scales. Mr. Campbell brought it from Lattakoo.
CARNIVORA.
103 Teeth of the CACHELoT, or sperm whale, Physeter macro-
cephalus.
104 Skull of a large SEAL, Phoca.
105 Ditto of a young TIGER, Felis tigris, from Benares.—Pre-
sented by Rev. W. P. Lyon.
106, 107 Head and feet of a LIoN, Felis leo.—Presented by Dr.
Thom.
108, 109 Ditto of a LioNEss, shot by Mr. Campbell’s party at
Buck’s Fountain, in the wild Bushmen’s country, May 19,
1823. The lion accompanying her was wounded, and es-
caped, but returned to search for her the following night.
110 The MANGOUSTE, Herpestes, from Travancore. Celebrated
for its combats with the most venomous serpents, and
from having made known the virtue of the Ophioriza
mungos as an antidote to their bite.
QUADRIMANA.
111 The RING-TaIe aa, Lemur catta. Inhabits Mada-
gascar, is good tempered, not so mischievous as a monkey,
and easily tamed when young.
On the Floor.
The GIRAFFE, or CAMELOPARD, shot in the Griqua Country,
South Africa, by Mr. Campbell’s party, July 31, 1814.
This specimen is sixteen feet high. The giraffe, although

1860 Catalogue, Page 52

Artefact Types Specimens in Natural History
Regions Africa,Americas,Unknown
Locations Interior of South Africa,Mashow country [Capital of the Ratlou Barolong, South Africa]

Transcription

(White.
NATURAL HISTORY.
52
but lately introduced to this country, was known to the
Romans; as it appears among the figures of Eastern ani-
mals in the celebrated Prænestine pavement, where it is
represented grazing and browsing; it was also exhibited
in the Circæan games.
Cranium, with the teeth and horns of a RHINOCÉkos, the R. simus
of Burchell. This great and formidable animal was sup-
posed by Mr. Campbell to be the UNICorN of the Scrip-
tures, Job xxxix. 9—12. The horn is 3 feet long. It
was shot by his party in the kingdom of Mashow, South
Africa, May 19, 1820, about 1200 miles north of the Cape.
A very young entire specimen,now in the British Museum,
was brought to England by the late Dr. A. Smith, who
says that the White Rhinoceros, as this species is called,
when full grown, is larger than either of the others: it
resorts more to the plains, its food being grass, and its
disposition being more gentle, is consequently looked
upon by the natives with less fear than is inspired by the
others.
Part of the head and horns of a Two-or RиIeros, R.
Ketloa of Dr. A. Smith. This was also killed in the
Mashow kingdom by Mr. Campbell’s party, May, 1820.
For a third species of Rhinoceros, see No. 92 in Case J.
Tusk of an Elephant.
Ditto of the NARWHALL, or sea unicorn, Monodon monoceros.
Stuffed skins of two large CROCODILEs, from the Lempopo river,
in the interior of South Africa.—Presented by the Rev. R.
Moffat.
A rare specimen of the boa constrictor and alligator in conflict.
-Presented by Rev. J. Ketley.
Over the door are horns of the following animals :—
1 The AXIS DEER, Cervus axis.
2—4 The Koupo, Antelope strepsiceros, Pallas.
5, 6 The HARTEBeESr, or CAA, A. bubulus, Linnæus, and A.
caama, Cuvier.
7, 8 The SPRING-BOK, A. euchore.

1860 Catalogue, Page 53

Artefact Types Specimens in Natural History
Regions Africa,Americas,Unknown
Locations Demerara [Guyana]

Transcription

53
White.)
NATURAL HISTORY.
9 The BoSH-Bok, A. sylvatica.
10 The GEMs-BoK, A. oryx, Pallas.
11 The TaHarrsI of the Bechuanas, and RoAN ANTELoe of the
Colonists, A. leucophæa, Gm.
12, 13 The CANNA, A. oreas, Pallas.
14 The Cape BUFFALo, Bos caffra, of large size : the flesh of
this animal served as food for Mr. Campbell’s party
several days.
Case P, on the top of the large Cases, contains
Fifteen various birds, including the Crow and the King Birds of
Paradise, two large Indian Kingfishers, Parrot, Hawk, &c.
Case Q.
BoA CONSTRICTOR in the act of destroying a fawn, from the neigh-
bourhood of Demerara.—Presented by Rev. Mr. Wray.
Case R.
A Mangouste, Ratel, earless Marmot, an Iguana, Monitor
lizard, and heads of two species of Buceros, or Hornbill.
Case S.
The STEIN-BoK, A. rupestris, and the KLIP SPRINGÉR, both from
Africa.—Presented by Rév. J. Campbell.
Case T.
Two examples of the FLYING MACAUCA, Galeopithecus volans, a
small brown Deer, the King Vulture, and four other birds.

1860 Catalogue, Page 54

Artefact Types Manufactures, Domestic Utensils,Specimens in Natural History
Regions Africa,Americas,Pacific,Unknown
Locations Africa,West Indies

Transcription

54
NATURAL HISTORY.
(White.
On the top of the Central Case
Is a very spirited representation of a Tiger, in needle-work.
The horizontal Case V
Contains various small shells from the West Indies, arranged in
compartments.—Presented by Mrs. Pirie.
In Case W
Are numerous bivalve shells of various genera, arranged and
labelled according to Lamarck, including the Balanus, or
acorn shell and duck barnacles, so troublesome on ships
bottoms: the Pholas and Lithodomus, that pierce holes
in stones and wood, Meleagrina; the pearl-bearing oyster;
Malleus, or hammer oyster, &c.
In Case X
The univalve shells are contained, also arranged and labelled
according to Lamarck; among them are Murex inflatus
and Pteroceras truncata.—Presented by the late Rev. J.
Williams. Several Harp shells, Tons and Cowries of
many kinds, with the pearly or chambered Nautilus, Ar¬
gonaut, &c., &c.
On one side of Case Y
Are various trachytic and scoriaceous Lavas, principally from
Hawaii, brought by Rev. W. Ellis; also a splendid
block of indurated yellow Asbestos, brought by Mr.
Campbell from the neighbourhood of the Orange River,
together with portions of the veins of the blue Asbestos,
of different thicknesses and states of induration; Mica,
stalactitic Lime, rhombic ditto, Prehnite, and varieties of
Iron ore, from Africa.

Notes

  1. ↩︎
  2. ↩︎
  3. ↩︎
  4. ↩︎

  6. ↩︎

  8. ↩︎

1860 Catalogue, Page 55

Artefact Types Specimens in Natural History
Regions Africa,Europe,Unknown
Locations Kythera, Greece

Transcription

NATURAL HISTORY.
White.)
On the other side
Are two rich blocks of Osseous Breccia and two gigantic fossil
oysters from Cerigo.—Presented by Rev. I. Lowndes. Also,
various vegetable productions, including the Phormium
tenax, or New Zealand flax, leaves of the Palmyra from
Travancore, seeds of the castor-oil plant, Ricinus commu-
nis, ditto of Coix lacryma, or Job’s tears, camel-thorn, the
thorn, in Africa called “stop awhile,” &c., &c.
Case Z in the Lobby
Contains the larger vegetable bodies, viz., two of the double, or
sea cocoa-nut, Lodoicea Sechellarium, base of the fronds
of a Polypodium, or Scythian lamb, embryo leaf of a palm,
various calabashes and gourds, cotton pods, seeds of
acacia, specimens of wood, the Bread fruit, &c., &c.
Two frames, containing twelve drawings of African flowers.-
Presented by Dr. Thom.
THE END.
London: Reed and Pardon, Printers, Paternoster-row.

Bibliography

Ardener, Edwin. 1985. Social Anthropology and the Decline of Modernism. In Reason and Morality, edited by J. Overing. London: Tavistock Publications.

Asad, Talal. 2003. Formations of the Secular: Christianity, Island, Modernity: Stanford University Press.

Bateson, Gregory. 1936. Naven : a survey of the problems suggested by a composite picture of the culture of a New Guinea tribe drawn from three points of view. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.

Bennett, Tony. 1988. The Exhibitionary Complex. new formations 4 (1):73-102.

Bhabha, Homi K. 1994. The location of culture. London: Routledge.

Clifford, James, and George E. Marcus. 1986. Writing culture : the poetics and politics of ethnography. Berkeley ; London: University of California Press.

Comaroff, Jean, and John L. Comaroff. 1991. Of revelation and revolution : Christianity, colonialism, and consciousness in South Africa. Chicago ; London: University of Chicago Press.

Comaroff, Jean, and John L. Comaroff. 1997. Of revelation and revolution : The Dialectics of Modernity on a South African Frontier. Chicago ; London: University of Chicago Press.

Fardon, Richard. 2005. Tiger in an Africa Palace. In The Qualities of Time: Anthropological Approaches, edited by W. James and D. Mills. Oxford: Berg.

Frazer, James George. 1911. The golden bough : a study in comparative religion. London: Macmillan.

Gellner, Ernest. 1987. Culture, Identity, and Politics: Cambridge University Press.

Goulder, Ben. 2007. Foucault and the Genealogy of Pastoral Power. Radical Philosophy Review 10 (2):157-176.

Graeber, David and David Wengrow. 2021. The Dawn of Everything; A New History of Humanity. London ; Penguin Random House.

Hilton, Boyd. 1988. The age of atonement : the influence of evangelicalism on social and economic thought, 1795-1865. Oxford: Clarendon Press.

Mirzoeff, Nicholas. 2011. The Right to Look: A Counterhistory of Visuality: Duke University Press.

North, Michael. 1999. Reading 1922: A Return to the Scene of the Modern: Oxford University Press.

Peel, J. D. Y. 1995. For Who Hath Despised the Day of Small Things? Missionary Narratives and Historical Anthropology. Comparative Studies in Society and History 37 (3):581-607.

Peel, J.D.Y. 2000. Religious Encounter and the Making of the Yoruba: Indiana University Press.

Stoler, Ann Laura. 2009. Along the archival grain: epistemic anxieties and colonial common sense. Princeton, N.J. ; Oxford: Princeton University Press.

Strathern, Marilyn. 1987. Out of Context: The Persuasive Fictions of Anthropology. _Current Anthropology_28:251-281.

Strathern, Marilyn. 1990. Artefacts of History: Events and the Interpretation of Images. In Culture and History in the Pacific, edited by J. Siikala. Helsinki: The Finnish Anthropological Society.

Wagner, Roy. 1981. The invention of culture. Rev. and expanded ed. Chicago: University of Chicago Press.

Young, Michael W. 1984. The Intensive Study of a Restricted Area, or, Why Did Malinowski Go to the Trobriand Islands? Oceania, 55(1), 1–26.

Young, Michael W. 2004. Malinowski: Odyssey of an Anthropologist, 1884-1920: Yale University Press.

Agee 1941
Agee, James, and Walker Evans. Let Us Now Praise Famous Men: Three Tenant Families. Boston: Houghton Mifflin, 1941.
Evans 1938
Evans, Walker. American Photographs. New York: Museum of Modern Art, 1938.
Lynd 1929
Lynd, Robert S., and Helen Merrell Lynd. Middletown: A Study in American Culture San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, 1929; reprint, Harvest/HBJ, 1956.

Contributors

  • Chris Wingfield
    With degrees in Archaeology & Anthropology as well as Material Anthropology and Museum Ethnography from the University of Oxford, I completed my PhD on the Museum of the London Missionary Society at the Department of Theology and Religion, University of Birmingham. Over the past two decades I have worked as a researcher at the Pitt Rivers Museum in Oxford, as a curator at Birmingham Museum & Art Gallery and the Museum of Archaeology & Anthropology in Cambridge, as well as at the Open University as an Associate Lecturer. Since 2018 I have worked at the Sainsbury Research Unit for the Arts of Africa, Oceania and the Americas at the University of East Anglia as Associate Professor in the Arts of Africa.
    • 12. A Gigantic Idol, twelve feet high: Avarua, Rarotonga, 6 May 1827
    • 13. All wrapped up in a piece of Tahitian cloth: Barmen, July 1832
    • 14. Paramasattee, a wooden idol with spoons attached
    • 15. The Departure of the Camden, Missionary Ship: New London Bridge, 11 April 1838
    • 16. Idol taken in the late war, from the chief temple at Chusan: Harbour of Chusan, 4 July 1840
    • 17. An exact model of a Bechuana house: Mission House, Blomfield Street, London, 23 January 1843
    • 18. A Rare Specimen of the Boa Constrictor and Alligator in Conflict: Providence New Chapel House, Georgetown, Demerara, 21 March 1849
    • 19. Rainitsontsoraka. Christian Martyr: Antananarivo, 25 September 1856
    • 20. Missions, Erromango, No. 725: Exposition Universelle, Paris, Summer 1867
    • 21. Representation of the Spirits of the Ancestors: Ujiji, Lake Tanganyika, 23 August 1878
    • 22. 72. Kāro. Fish trap. Baited inside. Made from Lorie palm.: British Museum, London, 8 March 1894
